Vocabulary.mean: When someone is afraid, they feel fear.
Vocabulary.example: The woman was afraid of what she saw.

Vocabulary.mean: To agree is to say “yes” or to think the same way.
Vocabulary.example: A: The food is very good in that restaurant. B: I agree with you.

Vocabulary.mean: When someone is angry, they may want to speak loudly or fight.
Vocabulary.example: She didn’t do her homework, so her father is angry.

Vocabulary.mean: To arrive is to get to or reach some place.
Vocabulary.example: The bus always arrives at the corner of my street at 4:00.

Vocabulary.mean: To attack is to try to fight or to hurt.
Vocabulary.example: The man with the sword attacked the other man first.

Vocabulary.mean: The bottom is the lowest part.
Vocabulary.example: The bottom of my shoe has a hole in it.

Vocabulary.mean: When someone is clever, they can solve a hard puzzle or problem.
Vocabulary.example: The clever boy thought of a good idea.

Vocabulary.mean: When someone is cruel, they do bad things to hurt others.
Vocabulary.example: The cruel man yelled at his sister.

Vocabulary.mean: If something happens finally, it happens after a longtime or at the end.
Vocabulary.example: He finally crossed the finish line after five hours of running.

Vocabulary.mean: To hide is to try not to let others see you.
Vocabulary.example: The other children will hide while you count to 100

Vocabulary.mean: To hunt is to look for or search for an animal to kill.
Vocabulary.example: Long ago, people hunted with bows and arrows.

Vocabulary.mean: A lot means a large number or amount of people, animals, things, etc.
Vocabulary.example: There are a lot of apples in the basket.

Vocabulary.mean: The middle of something is the center or halfway point.
Vocabulary.example: The Canadian flag has a maple leaf in the middle of it.

Vocabulary.mean: A moment is a second or a very short time.
Vocabulary.example: I was only a few moments late for the meeting.

Vocabulary.mean: When someone is pleased, they are happy.
Vocabulary.example: She was pleased with the phone call she received.

Vocabulary.mean: To promise is to say you will do something for sure.
Vocabulary.example: He promised to return my key by tomorrow.

Vocabulary.mean: To reply is to give an answer or say back to someone.
Vocabulary.example: She asked him what time his meeting was. He replied, “at three.”

Vocabulary.mean: When a person is safe, they are not in danger.
Vocabulary.example: Put on your seat belt in the car to be safe.

Vocabulary.mean: A trick is something you do to fool another person.
Vocabulary.example: His card trick really surprised us.

Vocabulary.mean: You use well to say that something was done in a good way.
Vocabulary.example: The couple can dance quite well.

Vocabulary.mean: An adventure is a fun or exciting thing that you do.
Vocabulary.example: Riding in the rough water was an adventure.

Vocabulary.mean: To approach something means to move close to it.
Vocabulary.example: The boy approached his school.

Vocabulary.mean: Carefully means with great attention, especially to detail or safety.
Vocabulary.example: The baby carefully climbed down the stairs.

Vocabulary.mean: A chemical is something that scientists use in chemistry.
Vocabulary.example: The scientist mixed the chemicals.

Vocabulary.mean: To create means to make something new.
Vocabulary.example: She created an igloo from blocks of snow.

Vocabulary.mean: Evil describes something or someone bad or cruel, not good.

Vocabulary.mean: An experiment is a test that you do to see what will happen.

Vocabulary.mean: To kill someone or something is to make them die.
Vocabulary.example: I killed the fly with a fly swatter.

Vocabulary.mean: A laboratory is a room where a scientist works.
Vocabulary.example: My mother works in a laboratory.

Vocabulary.mean: Laugh is the sound made when someone is happy or a funny thing occurs
Vocabulary.example: The sound of their laugh filled the room.

Vocabulary.mean: If a sound is loud, it is strong and very easy to hear.

Vocabulary.mean: When a person is nervous, they think something bad will happen.

Vocabulary.mean: A noise is an unpleasant sound.
Vocabulary.example: The crying baby made a loud noise.

Vocabulary.mean: A project is a type of work that you do for school or a job.

Vocabulary.mean: To scare someone is to make them feel afraid.

Vocabulary.mean: A secret is something that you do not tell other people.

Vocabulary.mean: To shout is to say something loudly.

Vocabulary.mean: To smell something means to use your nose to sense it.
Vocabulary.example: The girl smelled the flower.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is terrible, it is very bad.

Vocabulary.mean: An alien is a creature from a different world.

Vocabulary.mean: Instead means in place of.

Vocabulary.mean: A report is something students write for school.
Vocabulary.example: John had trouble writing his report.

Vocabulary.mean: Several is more than two but not many.

Vocabulary.mean: To solve something is to find an answer to it.

Vocabulary.mean: The universe is the known or supposed objects in space.

Vocabulary.mean: When a thing is appropriate, it is right or normal.

Vocabulary.mean: To avoid something is to stay away from it.

Vocabulary.mean: Concern is a feeling of worry.

Vocabulary.mean: To continue something is to keep doing it.

Vocabulary.mean: To hurt is to do something that makes you feel pain.

Vocabulary.mean: To request something is to ask for it.

Vocabulary.mean: To be dead is to not be alive.

Vocabulary.mean: A pet is an animal that lives with people.

Vocabulary.mean: To survive is to stay alive.

Vocabulary.example: The men tried to steal wallet.

Vocabulary.example: A thief broke into our home and took my mother'slaptop.

Vocabulary.mean: To advance is to go forward.
Vocabulary.example: He advanced up the ladder slowly.

Vocabulary.mean: An athlete is a person who plays sports.
Vocabulary.example: Some athletes can play many sports very well.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is average, it is at a normal level.
Vocabulary.example: I’m not rich or poor; I’m average.

Vocabulary.mean: Your behavior is the way you act.
Vocabulary.example: Their behavior was good this semester. They didn’t cause trouble.

Vocabulary.mean: Behind means to be at the back of something.
Vocabulary.example: The little girl was hiding behind a tree.

Vocabulary.mean: A course is a class in school.

Vocabulary.mean: To lower something is to make it go down.
Vocabulary.example: The chart shows how his production has lowered over the year.

Vocabulary.mean: To match is to be the same or similar.
Vocabulary.example: The two shoes matched. They looked the same.

Vocabulary.mean: A member is a person who is part of a group.
Vocabulary.example: Julie is the newest member of our team.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is mental, it has to do with your mind.
Vocabulary.example: I made a mental picture of the room.

Vocabulary.mean: A passenger is a person who rides in a car, train, or airplane.
Vocabulary.example: Some passengers were standing in the subway train.

Vocabulary.mean: Your personality is what you are like and how you behave.
Vocabulary.example: John has a bad personality.

Vocabulary.mean: A poem is a short kind of writing.
Vocabulary.example: William Shakespeare wrote many poems.

Vocabulary.mean: A pole is a long thin stick made of wood or metal that supports things.
Vocabulary.example: The flag was hanging from the flag pole.

Vocabulary.mean: To remove something is to take it away.
Vocabulary.example: I removed the nail from the board.

Vocabulary.mean: Safety means to be the condition of being safe and free from danger.
Vocabulary.example: For his own safety, he was placed in a car seat.

Vocabulary.mean: To shoot is to fire something like a bullet at someone or something.
Vocabulary.example: The woman raised her gun to shoot at the target.

Vocabulary.mean: To sound means to make a noise.
Vocabulary.example: The alarm clock sounded and woke us all up.

Vocabulary.mean: To swim is to move through water.
Vocabulary.example: I love to swim in the ocean.

Vocabulary.mean: A web is a home made by a spider.

Vocabulary.mean: A block is a solid piece of wood, stone or ice.
Vocabulary.example: I saw a block of ice on the floor.

Vocabulary.mean: To cheer is to give a loud shout of approval or encouragement.
Vocabulary.example: The crowd all cheered when the home team won.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is complex, it has many small parts. It is hard to understan
Vocabulary.example: A jigpuzzle can be complex because it has so many pieces.

Vocabulary.mean: A critic is someone who give their opinions about movies, books, plays
Vocabulary.example: The wine critic tasted the wine so he could give his opinion.

Vocabulary.mean: An event is something that happens, especially something important.
Vocabulary.example: Finishing high school was a major event in his life.

Vocabulary.mean: To exercise is to run or play sports so that you can be healthy.
Vocabulary.example: You should exercise every day.

Vocabulary.mean: If something fits, it is small enough orthe right size to go there.
Vocabulary.example: The eggs fit into the box.

Vocabulary.mean: Friendship is the relationship between people who are friends.
Vocabulary.example: Michael and Lisa have a very strong friendship with each other.

Vocabulary.mean: A guide is someone who shows you where to go.
Vocabulary.example: We followed a guide at the park.

Vocabulary.mean: If there is a lack of something, there is not enough of it.
Vocabulary.example: His only problem is a lack of money.

Vocabulary.mean: A passage is a long area with walls that goes from one place to another
Vocabulary.example: The long passage led us to the other side of the field.

Vocabulary.mean: To perform is to do something in front of people who watch.
Vocabulary.example: They will perform a song for the class.

Vocabulary.mean: Pressure is what you apply to make someone do something.
Vocabulary.example: They put pressure on him to change his mind.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is probable, it is likely to happen.
Vocabulary.example: It is probable that you will get a good grade if you study for the test.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is public, it is meant for everyone to use.
Vocabulary.example: I went to the public park to play with my friends.

Vocabulary.mean: To strike someone or something is to hit them.
Vocabulary.example: My golf was terrible today - I just didn't strike the ball well.

Vocabulary.mean: To support something is to like it and help it be successful.
Vocabulary.example: Everyone at work supports the new plan.

Vocabulary.mean: A task is work that someone has to do.
Vocabulary.example: Who has the task of building the brick wall?

Vocabulary.mean: A term is a word for something.

Vocabulary.mean: To unite is to get together to do something.

Vocabulary.mean: To associate means to connect something with a person or thing.
Vocabulary.example: Most people associate birthday parties with having fun.

Vocabulary.mean: The environment is the place where people work or live.
Vocabulary.example: Keeping our environment clean is important to our health.

Vocabulary.mean: A factory is a building where things are made or put together.
Vocabulary.example: We have only one factory in our town.

Vocabulary.mean: A feature is an important part of something.
Vocabulary.example: The cell phone has many features.

Vocabulary.mean: An instance is an example of something.
Vocabulary.example: I have never experienced an instance of hate. Have you?

Vocabulary.mean: To involve means to be actively taking part in something.
Vocabulary.example: The whole family was involved in playing the game.

Vocabulary.mean: Medicine is something you take to feel better or treat an illness.
Vocabulary.example: The doctor gave me medicine for my cold.

Vocabulary.mean: A mix is different things put together.
Vocabulary.example: Many kinds of nut are mixed in a bowl

Vocabulary.mean: To organize is to plan or get ready for an event.
Vocabulary.example: Make a list to help you organize the things you need.

Vocabulary.mean: A period is an amount of time when something happens.
Vocabulary.example: In one period in Europe, there were many knights.

Vocabulary.mean: If people populate an area, they live there.
Vocabulary.example: Billions of people populate the Earth.

Vocabulary.mean: To produce something is to make or grow it.
Vocabulary.example: This tree produces apples every year.

Vocabulary.mean: A range is a number or a set of similar things.
Vocabulary.example: I saw a range of cars to choose from.

Vocabulary.mean: To recognize something is to know it because you have seen it before.
Vocabulary.example: I recognized an old friend from many years ago.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is regular, it happens often and in equal amounts of time.
Vocabulary.example: Our regular lunch time is around noon.

Vocabulary.example: It's raining, which is a sign of a bad day

Vocabulary.mean: A tip is a pointed end of something.
Vocabulary.example: The tip of his pen was very sharp.

Vocabulary.mean: A tradition is something people have been doing for a long time.
Vocabulary.example: In keeping with tradition, they always have turkey on Christmas Day.

Vocabulary.mean: Trash is waste material or unwanted or worthless things.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is wide, it is large from side to side.

Vocabulary.example: I don’t know how to study for my exams. Can you give me some advice?

Vocabulary.mean: Attention is the notice, thought, or consideration of someone.
Vocabulary.example: His work got the attention of two of his co-workers.

Vocabulary.mean: To attract means to make a person or thing come closer or be intereste
Vocabulary.example: The magnet attracted the metal.

Vocabulary.mean: To climb means to use your hands and feet to go up on something.
Vocabulary.example: The girls climbed to the top of the mountain.

Vocabulary.mean: To drop is to fall or allow something to fall.
Vocabulary.example: A small amount of water dropped from the tap.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is final, it is the last part.
Vocabulary.example: In the final part of the film, the man and the woman got married.

Vocabulary.mean: Further is used to say something is from a distance or time.

Vocabulary.mean: To imply something is to suggest it without saying it.
Vocabulary.example: The man implied that he wanted the job, but he didn’t say so.

Vocabulary.mean: To maintain means to make something stay the same.
Vocabulary.example: The balls maintain constant movement.

Vocabulary.example: Neither the pass on the left nor the pass on the right will lead us home.

Vocabulary.mean: Otherwise means different or in another way.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is physical, it is related to your body and not your mind.
Vocabulary.example: Biking is good for your physical health.

Vocabulary.mean: To prove something is to show that it is true.
Vocabulary.example: My teacher proved the answer on the board.

Vocabulary.mean: To react is to act in a certain way because of something that happened.
Vocabulary.example: James reacted badly to the news.

Vocabulary.mean: To ride something is to travel on it. You can ride an animal, a bike, etc.
Vocabulary.example: I will ride a rollerfor the first time today.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is situated somewhere, it is in that place.
Vocabulary.example: My bedroom was situated on the top floor of the house.

Vocabulary.mean: Society is people and the way that they live.

Vocabulary.mean: A standard is what people consider normal or good.

Vocabulary.mean: To suggest something means to give an idea or plan about it.
Vocabulary.example: He suggested that I try a new product.

Vocabulary.mean: Actually means in fact or really.

Vocabulary.mean: Bite is the act of using your teeth to cut and tear into something.

Vocabulary.mean: The coast is the land by an ocean.

Vocabulary.mean: A deal is an agreement that you have with another person.
Vocabulary.example: I made a deal with the other company to give us some money.

Vocabulary.mean: The desert is an area of land without many plants or water.
Vocabulary.example: Not many plants grow in the desert.

Vocabulary.mean: An earthquake is a shaking movement of the ground.
Vocabulary.example: The building shook during the earthquake.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is effective, it works well.
Vocabulary.example: Swimming is an effective way to stay healthy.

Vocabulary.mean: To examine something is to look at it carefully.
Vocabulary.example: The doctor examined my eyes today.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is false, it is not correct.

Vocabulary.mean: A gift is something you give someone.

Vocabulary.mean: Hunger is the feeling that you get when you need to eat.
Vocabulary.example: After playing all day long, she was filled with hunger.

Vocabulary.mean: To imagine something is to think of it in your mind.
Vocabulary.example: Sally imagined herself winning lots of money.

Vocabulary.mean: A journey is a long trip.
Vocabulary.example: I went on a journey across the country with my parents.

Vocabulary.mean: A puzzle is something that is hard to understand.
Vocabulary.example: The question was a puzzle to him.

Vocabulary.mean: Quite is used to say that something is complete or very much.
Vocabulary.example: I think typing on a keyboard is quite easy.

Vocabulary.mean: Rather is used when you want to do one thing but not the other.
Vocabulary.example: I would rather have the red one than the green one.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is specific, it is precise or exact.

Vocabulary.mean: A trip is a journey to a certain place.

Vocabulary.mean: If something has value, it is worth a lot of money.

Vocabulary.mean: A band is a group of people who play music.

Vocabulary.mean: Barely means by the smallest amount, almost not.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is boring, it is not fun.

Vocabulary.example: She cancelled the rest of her plans because of the rain.

Vocabulary.mean: A driveway is a short private road that leads to a person’s home.

Vocabulary.mean: Garbage is waste material like unwanted or spoiled food, bottles, paper, etc.
Vocabulary.example: The boy cleaned up the garbage around his house.

Vocabulary.mean: An instrument is something designed to do a certain task like music.
Vocabulary.example: My favorite musical instrument is the piano.

Vocabulary.mean: A list is a record of information printed with an item on each line.
Vocabulary.example: My mom makes a list of groceries to buy.

Vocabulary.mean: Magic is the power to do impossible things.

Vocabulary.mean: A message is a set of words that you send to someone.

Vocabulary.mean: A schedule is a plan that tells you when to do things.

Vocabulary.mean: A stage is a place where actors or musicians act or sing.

Vocabulary.mean: Respect is a good opinion of someone because they are good.

Vocabulary.mean: Honesty means the quality of being truthful or honest.

Vocabulary.mean: A master is a person who is very good at something.

Vocabulary.mean: A memory is something you remember.

Vocabulary.mean: A landscape is how an area of land looks.

Vocabulary.mean: To remark is to say something.

Vocabulary.mean: To seek is to look for something.

Vocabulary.mean: To shine is to make a bright light.

Vocabulary.mean: To spill is to have something fall out of its container.

Vocabulary.mean: To bring means to take someone or something to a person or place.

Vocabulary.mean: A castle is a building with strong walls where royalty usually lives.

Vocabulary.mean: To command someone is to tell them to do something.
Vocabulary.example: The general commanded his army to attack.

Vocabulary.mean: To counsel someone is to listen and give advice about a problem.
Vocabulary.example: The teacher counseled the boy about his troubles.

Vocabulary.mean: To ensure is to make certain that something happens.
Vocabulary.example: Eating good food ensures that we stay healthy.

Vocabulary.mean: An explosion is a violent burst, usually with a loud sound.
Vocabulary.example: A nuclear explosion can cause great damage.

Vocabulary.mean: Jewelry is something that people wear like earrings or necklaces.

Vocabulary.mean: To land means to come to the ground usually from a ship or aircraft.

Vocabulary.mean: A meteor is a rock from outer space that falls to Earth.

Vocabulary.mean: A weed is a plant, especially one that is not useful or wanted.

Vocabulary.mean: A bow is a weapon made of curved wood and string that shoots arrows.

Vocabulary.mean: A chief is the leader of a group of people.

Vocabulary.mean: If something hardly happens, it almost does not happen at all.

Vocabulary.mean: Laughter is the sound produced by laughing about something funny.
Vocabulary.example: Susan’s joke made her classmates burst into laughter.

Vocabulary.mean: A log is a thick piece of wood that is cut from a tree.
Vocabulary.example: The fire was too small, so we added another log to it.

Vocabulary.mean: The military is the armed forces of a country.
Vocabulary.example: I joined the military after I finished high school.

Vocabulary.mean: To obey means to follow what a law or a person says you must do.
Vocabulary.example: My little sister did not obey my mother. Now she is in trouble.

Vocabulary.mean: To secure something means to get it after a lot of effort.
Vocabulary.example: I was able to secure a good grade on my test after weeks of studying.

Vocabulary.mean: When someone or something is steady, they are under control.

Vocabulary.mean: To trust is to believe that someone is honest and will do what is right.
Vocabulary.example: I trust my friends; they don’t tell my secrets to other people.

Vocabulary.mean: To twist something is to wrap it around itself or another thing.
Vocabulary.example: She twisted the spaghetti around her fork.

Vocabulary.mean: A weapon is an object that can be used to hurt people.

Vocabulary.mean: If you have confidence about something, you are sure of it.
Vocabulary.example: I have confidence that I did well on the test.

Vocabulary.mean: A consequence is a result of a choice or action.

Vocabulary.mean: To estimate something means to make a guess about it.

Vocabulary.mean: When you honor people or things, you show respect for them.

Vocabulary.mean: A marathon is a very long foot race just over 42 kilometers.

Vocabulary.mean: When someone or something is sensitive, they are easily hurt.

Vocabulary.mean: An angle is the direction from which you look at something.

Vocabulary.mean: To congratulate someone is to tell them that you are happy for them.

Vocabulary.mean: If people or things are lovely, they are goodor beautiful.

Vocabulary.mean: To sprinkle means to scatter something all over something else.
Vocabulary.example: He sprinkled the pasta with salt and black pepper.

Vocabulary.mean: If food is stale, then it is not fresh but dry, hard, and not good to eat.
Vocabulary.example: The cookies sat on the table so long that They became stale.

Vocabulary.mean: To utter a word or a sound means to say it.
Vocabulary.example: The lost boy was so scared that he could barely utter a single word.

Vocabulary.mean: You use although to say that one thing is contrasted by another.
Vocabulary.example: Although she was late, her friends gave her a warm welcome.

Vocabulary.mean: To apply something means to put it on.
Vocabulary.example: She always applies makeup to her face before going outside.

Vocabulary.mean: To await something means to wait for it.
Vocabulary.example: The players awaited the judge’s decision.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is beloved, it is very special and you like it very much.
Vocabulary.example: The boy took a nap next to his beloved cat.

Vocabulary.mean: To bury someone or something means to put them in the ground.
Vocabulary.example: They buried their grandfather under his favorite tree after he died.

Vocabulary.mean: A climate is the usual weather in a place.
Vocabulary.example: The climate in the desert is very hot.

Vocabulary.mean: When you complain, you say that you are unhappy about something.
Vocabulary.example: The workers complained that they were being treated unfairly.

Vocabulary.mean: To confuse someone means to make them feel like they are unsure.
Vocabulary.example: The sign confused the traveler because it pointed in two directions.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is due, it is expected to happen or be done at that time.
Vocabulary.example: The papers were due on the 19th.

Vocabulary.mean: When you talk about an entire thing, you are talking about the whole thing.
Vocabulary.example: He was so hungry that he ate the entire pizza by himself.

Vocabulary.mean: To establish something means to create it.
Vocabulary.example: He wanted to establish a club for people to help the Earth.

Vocabulary.mean: A furnace is a place where heat is made.
Vocabulary.example: Mr. Jones came to fix the furnace.

Vocabulary.mean: A leash is a rope or chain that is used to lead an animal.
Vocabulary.example: A lot of dogs must wear a leash to keep them from running away.

Vocabulary.mean: To mature means to grow up to become an adult.
Vocabulary.example: When they matured, they became as tall as their parents.

Vocabulary.mean: To measure something means to find out the quality, value, or effect of it.
Vocabulary.example: The scientists carefully measured the amount of chemicals in the tubes.

Vocabulary.mean: The midst of something is the middle of it.
Vocabulary.example: She was in the midst of cleaning when the telephone rang.

Vocabulary.mean: Misery is extreme suffering.
Vocabulary.example: There was a lot of misery after Sam lost his dog.

Vocabulary.mean: When something happened prior to something else, it happened earlier.
Vocabulary.example: Ron had to wait since he arrived prior to the scheduled meeting time.

Vocabulary.mean: Research is close and careful study to discover new things.
Vocabulary.example: Scientists did a lot of research on the subject of blood type.

Vocabulary.mean: A variety of something is a group of many different kinds of it.
Vocabulary.example: There are a variety of flowers at the shop.

Vocabulary.mean: If something happens altogether, it happens completely.
Vocabulary.example: The company stopped using sugar altogether in its food.

Vocabulary.mean: To bind is to bring people together.
Vocabulary.example: The victims of the flood were bound by their need to help each other.

Vocabulary.mean: A bruise is a dark mark caused by being hit by something.
Vocabulary.example: She got a bruise on her knee from falling down.

Vocabulary.mean: A custom is a way of doing things that has been the same for a long time.
Vocabulary.example: It is a custom that the bride and groom have the first dance.

Vocabulary.mean: When someone is disobedient, they do not follow the rules or instructions.
Vocabulary.example: The disobedient children didn’t listen to their mother and had an accident.

Vocabulary.mean: To foresee something is to know about it before it happens.
Vocabulary.example: The teacher didn’t foresee any problems with her large class.

Vocabulary.mean: To glimpse something is to see it for a short time.
Vocabulary.example: She glimpsed outside the window as the plane was about to land.

Vocabulary.mean: A hoop is a ring that is made of plastic, metal, or wood.
Vocabulary.example: The boys tried to toss the ball through the basketball hoop.

Vocabulary.mean: Misfortune is bad luck or an unlucky event.
Vocabulary.example: His family helped him when he encountered misfortune.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is negative, it is unpleasant or sad.
Vocabulary.example: She doesn’t like to say negative things about her friends.

Vocabulary.mean: Per is used to mean “each” when giving a price, size, or amount.
Vocabulary.example: It costs $8 per person to watch the baseball game.

Vocabulary.mean: To plead is to ask for something you want very badly.
Vocabulary.example: He pleaded for his parents to let him go to the soccer game.

Vocabulary.mean: To rip something means to pull it apart.
Vocabulary.example: She ripped the paper in half by accident.

Vocabulary.mean: The sake of something is the reason for doing it.
Vocabulary.example: The parents worked hard for their children’s sake.

Vocabulary.mean: To scrape something is to rub it very hard with something sharp.
Vocabulary.example: I accidentally scraped the paint off the side of the car.

Vocabulary.mean: A source of something is the place that it comes from.
Vocabulary.example: The river was the source of drinking water for the village.

Vocabulary.mean: When somebody is stern, they are very serious.
Vocabulary.example: The stern teacher didn’t allow the students to speak during class.

Vocabulary.mean: To stitch is to use a needle and thread to join pieces of cloth together.
Vocabulary.example: My grandmother stitched the pieces together to make a big blanket.

Vocabulary.mean: A thump is the sound of a heavy object falling.
Vocabulary.example: They heard the thump when the bowling ball hit the floor.

Vocabulary.mean: When somebody is vehement, they are angry and emotional.
Vocabulary.example: Gina was vehement when She found out that Liz was bad in school.

Vocabulary.mean: A civilization is an organized group of humans that have culture and government
Vocabulary.example: Most early civilizations in Central America didn’t use metal weapons.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is convenient, it is easy to do and does not take a lot of work.
Vocabulary.example: The bus is a convenient way to get to school.

Vocabulary.mean: A den is a living space for some types of animals, such as lions.
Vocabulary.example: The mother lion left her babies in the den.

Vocabulary.mean: Dew is the drops of water that form on the ground outside during the night.
Vocabulary.example: When we woke up, we saw that the grass was covered in dew.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is drastic, it is extreme or major.
Vocabulary.example: She made a drastic decision to get her long hair cut short.

Vocabulary.mean: To exit means to leave.
Vocabulary.example: The students exited through the front door.

Vocabulary.mean: A flock is a group of animals, such as birds, sheep or goats.
Vocabulary.example: There was one black sheep in the entire flock.

Vocabulary.mean: To fold is to bend something like paper or cloth so that it takes up less space.
Vocabulary.example: I folded the paper and put it in my pocket.

Vocabulary.mean: A lid is a top for a box or container that can be removed.
Vocabulary.example: He lifted the lid of the box and revealed her present.

Vocabulary.mean: To loom is to seem very large and often scary.
Vocabulary.example: The ominous clouds loomed over the school.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is mighty, it is strong and large.
Vocabulary.example: The mighty wrestler scared all who faced him.

Vocabulary.mean: A mushroom is a fungus with a round top. Some are used as food.
Vocabulary.example: The soup had fresh mushrooms in it.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is native, it is originating in a certain place or area.
Vocabulary.example: Avocadoes are native fruits of Mexico.

Vocabulary.mean: Poison is a dangerous substance that causes illness or death.
Vocabulary.example: They used poison to get rid of the rats in their home.

Vocabulary.mean: Reeds are tall and skinny plants that grow in groups near water.
Vocabulary.example: The sun set behind the reeds of the lake’s shore.

Vocabulary.mean: To shield something is to protect it.
Vocabulary.example: She shielded her eyes from the sun with sunglasses.

Vocabulary.mean: Stormy describes something affected or characterized by storms.
Vocabulary.example: The golfers decided to go home because of the stormy weather.

Vocabulary.mean: To sway is to move slowly from side to side.
Vocabulary.example: She swayed while she listened to the music.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is urban, it is related to the city.
Vocabulary.example: Subways are an important form of urban transportation.

Vocabulary.mean: To wade is to walk in or pass through water.
Vocabulary.example: The child waded in the water at the beach.

Vocabulary.mean: An accent is a certain way of speaking that shows where a person is from.
Vocabulary.example: The new teacher’s accent was clearly a German one.

Vocabulary.mean: A barber is a person whose job is to cut hair.
Vocabulary.example: My hair is getting much too long. I’d better go to the barber’s shop.

Vocabulary.mean: A basement of a house or building is a room that is built underground.
Vocabulary.example: They turned their basement into a game room.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is blank, it does not have anything on it.
Vocabulary.example: She got a blank paper to draw on.

Vocabulary.mean: To blink means to shut the eyes and quickly open them again.
Vocabulary.example: I blinked many times so that my eyes could adjust to the bright light.

Vocabulary.mean: A choir is a group of people who sing together.
Vocabulary.example: He had choir practice every day after school.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is comic, it is funny.
Vocabulary.example: The comic actor was famous for his jokes.

Vocabulary.mean: To complicate something means to make it harder than necessary.
Vocabulary.example: The bad weather complicated finishing the job quickly.

Vocabulary.mean: To decline an offer or invitation means to say no to it.
Vocabulary.example: She declined his offer to pay for her dinner.

Vocabulary.mean: An errand is a trip taken to do a specific activity.
Vocabulary.example: He couldn’t go to practice because He had several errands to do.

Vocabulary.mean: A glove is a piece of clothing that covers your fingers and hand.
Vocabulary.example: When it gets cold, I always put on a pair of gloves.

Vocabulary.mean: A hermit is one who lives alone and does not spend time with others.
Vocabulary.example: The hermit lived a simple life in a small cave in the forest.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is done justly, then it is fair.
Vocabulary.example: We justly decided to give the prize to him.

Vocabulary.mean: Leather is a material made from animal skin that is used to make clothing.
Vocabulary.example: He got a new leather jacket for his birthday.

Vocabulary.mean: To ponder something is to think about it carefully.
Vocabulary.example: She sat in the park and pondered her problem.

Vocabulary.mean: To reserve something means to keep it for a certain person or time.
Vocabulary.example: He reserved a table at the busy restaurant.

Vocabulary.mean: A script is the words of a film or play.
Vocabulary.example: He read the script of the play three times.

Vocabulary.mean: To search for something or someone means to look for them carefully.
Vocabulary.example: I searched the newspaper for a new job.

Vocabulary.mean: To slam is to close something hard.
Vocabulary.example: She slammed the book shut after she finished reading it.

Vocabulary.mean: A staircase is a set of stairs found inside a building.
Vocabulary.example: The staircase leads directly into the kitchen.

Vocabulary.mean: Afflicted means to suffer physically or mentally.
Vocabulary.example: He was afflicted by pain in his right arm.

Vocabulary.mean: An aisle is a space between two things that people use to walk.
Vocabulary.example: They were told to clear the aisle because the plane was about to land.

Vocabulary.mean: The atmosphere is the air around the Earth where weather conditions form.
Vocabulary.example: Scientists worry that harmful substances are hurting the atmosphere.

Vocabulary.mean: An author is a person who wrote a certain piece of writing.
Vocabulary.example: The author was hard at work on his next novel.

Vocabulary.mean: A breakdown is a failure to work correctly.
Vocabulary.example: Her car had a breakdown, and she wasn’t sure howto fix it.

Vocabulary.mean: Cargo is the items carried by a ship or airplane.
Vocabulary.example: The cargo of the ship got wet when it started raining.

Vocabulary.mean: A chapter is a part of a book that usually has a number or a title.
Vocabulary.example: The first chapter of a book usually introduces the main character of a story.

Vocabulary.mean: To connect two things means to join them together.
Vocabulary.example: I connected the mouse to my laptop computer.

Vocabulary.mean: Etc. is short for “etcetera.” It is used to refer to other unspecified objects.
Vocabulary.example: She was going to bring treats to the party: cookies, muffins, cake, etc.

Vocabulary.mean: To flip means to press a switch quickly to turn it on or off.
Vocabulary.example: To turn on the lights, just flip this switch.

Vocabulary.mean: If you are idle, you are not doing anything.
Vocabulary.example: She read a book to keep from being idle.

Vocabulary.mean: To notify someone of something is to tell them about it.
Vocabulary.example: The teacher notified us about a change to our assignment.

Vocabulary.mean: Peas are a vegetable that is small, round and green.
Vocabulary.example: His favorite food was peas.

Vocabulary.mean: A raisin is a dried grape.
Vocabulary.example: Raisins are one of my favorite snacks.

Vocabulary.mean: To retain something is to keep it.
Vocabulary.example: Even by the afternoon, the day had retained the morning’s freshness.

Vocabulary.mean: To state something means to say it in a definite way.
Vocabulary.example: The president stated his opinion about the world’s health concerns.

Vocabulary.mean: A tray is a flat plate used to hold food.
Vocabulary.example: The waiter brought our food on a tray.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is unfortunate, it is bad or unlucky.
Vocabulary.example: It was unfortunate that Dave’s team lost, but he still had fun.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is vivid, it is bright and colorful.
Vocabulary.example: The figures in the painting were vivid.

Vocabulary.mean: To vomit means to have food come up from one’s stomach.
Vocabulary.example: It is common for women to vomit when they are pregnant.

Vocabulary.mean: To betray someone means to treat them in a dishonest way.
Vocabulary.example: The man betrayed his country when he gave away national secrets.

Vocabulary.mean: A blast is a loud noise made by something that explodes.
Vocabulary.example: There was a loud blast when the police officer fired the gun.

Vocabulary.mean: A bracelet is a piece of jewelry that you wear around your wrist.
Vocabulary.example: My father gave me a pretty gold bracelet for my birthday.

Vocabulary.mean: To cease means to stop.
Vocabulary.example: After about an hour, the rain ceased, and a rainbow appeared.

Vocabulary.mean: To choke means to cough because you have difficulty breathing.
Vocabulary.example: There was a lot of smoke in the air, and it made me choke.

Vocabulary.mean: When an event is civil, it happens inside a country.
Vocabulary.example: The country was torn apart by a terrible civil war.

Vocabulary.mean: To comment means to say something that shows your personal opinion.
Vocabulary.example: Tom commented on the poor quality of the food.

Vocabulary.mean: To cross means to go from one side to the other side.
Vocabulary.example: We used his boat to cross to the other side of the lake.

Vocabulary.mean: A dent is damage caused by something heavy hitting something else.
Vocabulary.example: That blue car hit my car, and now there is a small dent in my car door.

Vocabulary.mean: To distrust someone means to believe that they are not honest.
Vocabulary.example: Don’t lend money to someone if you distrust them!

Vocabulary.mean: A fort is a small building that is specially built to defend an area from attack.
Vocabulary.example: When the army arrived, they built a big fort on the top of the hill.

Vocabulary.mean: To found means to bring something into existence.
Vocabulary.example: The pastor founded his church in the countryside.

Vocabulary.mean: Lining is a piece of cloth that covers the inside of clothes.
Vocabulary.example: This jacket is very warm because it has a thick lining.

Vocabulary.mean: A mass is a large number of things of one type.
Vocabulary.example: We received a mass of letters this morning.

Vocabulary.mean: To pray means to talk to God.
Vocabulary.example: When people go to church, they pray for their families and friends.

Vocabulary.mean: If a place is rife with something bad, it is very common in that place.
Vocabulary.example: This part of the country is rife with disease.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is the sole thing, it is the only thing of a particular type.
Vocabulary.example: His sole purpose in life was to help others.

Vocabulary.mean: If you sweep the floor, you clean it with a tool like a broom or a brush.
Vocabulary.example: There is a lot of dirt on the floor. can you sweep it please?

Vocabulary.mean: Treachery is a behavior in which a person betrays a country or a person.
Vocabulary.example: The man ran away to escape from the treachery of his wife.

Vocabulary.mean: To tuck something means to put it somewhere so that it is neat or safe.
Vocabulary.example: He looked sloppy without his shirt being tucked into his pants.

Vocabulary.mean: A background is a person’s education, family, and experience.
Vocabulary.example: The new teacher had a background in science and math.

Vocabulary.mean: Bait is something used to trick a person or thing to do something.
Vocabulary.example: The best bait for catching fish is a big, fat worm.

Vocabulary.mean: To chronicle something means to record an event or speech.
Vocabulary.example: The daily newspaper chronicles local and world events.

Vocabulary.mean: Copper is a redmetal often used in electric wire and pipes.
Vocabulary.example: Ancient hunters melted copper to make knives and spears.

Vocabulary.mean: A disease is an illness that causes specific problems.
Vocabulary.example: He had a disease that caused him to lose his hearing.

Vocabulary.mean: Folklore is the collection of beliefs and stories of a culture.
Vocabulary.example: India’s folklore has stories written in long poems about great warriors.

Vocabulary.mean: To infect someone means to give them an illness.
Vocabulary.example: The common cold infects hundreds of millions of people each year.

Vocabulary.mean: To itch means to rub the skin with your fingernails.
Vocabulary.example: The rough fabric in his shirt made the back of his neck itch.

Vocabulary.mean: Literature is books, plays, and poetry.
Vocabulary.example: Early American literature covers the poetry and stories from 1500 to 1800.

Vocabulary.mean: A millennium is one thousand years.
Vocabulary.example: Stonehenge is believed to have been built about 5 millenniums ago.

Vocabulary.mean: A myth is a traditional story that explains a culture’s history and beliefs.
Vocabulary.example: In Greece, there was a myth about a woman who had snakes for hair.

Vocabulary.mean: To promote someone means to raise them to a higher position or rank.
Vocabulary.example: After two years in the company, she was promoted to a manager.

Vocabulary.mean: To relate to something means to have a connection with it.
Vocabulary.example: A company’s plan usually relates to how much profit it can make.

Vocabulary.mean: A religion is a belief in a god or gods.
Vocabulary.example: Their religion taught that people should forgive their enemies.

Vocabulary.mean: A sum is a specific amount of money.
Vocabulary.example: He calculated the numbers to see what the sum of his bills would be.

Vocabulary.mean: A teller is a person who works with a bank’s customers.
Vocabulary.example: The teller at the bank helped Kelly put money into a savings account.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone is trustworthy, they are honest and truthful.
Vocabulary.example: Mary is one of the most trustworthy people I’ve ever met.

Vocabulary.mean: To update something means to make it more modern.
Vocabulary.example: We need to update the programs on our computers.

Vocabulary.mean: A vein is a tube in the body that carries blood toward the heart.
Vocabulary.example: The blue veins in my hand are just under my skin.

Vocabulary.mean: Venom is a poisonous substance that comes from animals or plants.
Vocabulary.example: A snake’s venom can be used to cure the illnesses it creates.

Vocabulary.mean: Charity is an act of giving help, usually money, to those who need it.
Vocabulary.example: Thanks to his friends’ charity, he had enough money to pay the rent.

Vocabulary.mean: Commerce is the activity of buying and selling things.
Vocabulary.example: The new shopping mall increased the commerce in that section of town.

Vocabulary.mean: To condemn someone means to give them a specific punishment.
Vocabulary.example: The judge condemned the criminal to five years in prison.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is cozy, then it is comfortable, warm, and relaxing.
Vocabulary.example: The thick blanket made the bed very cozy.

Vocabulary.mean: To deplete an amount of something means to use up all of it.
Vocabulary.example: All the driving he was doing was depleting his car’s fuel supply.

Vocabulary.mean: An economy is the money and businesses of a country or region.
Vocabulary.example: The factory was good for the economy because it brought jobs to the area.

Vocabulary.mean: An empire is a large group of countries ruled by an emperor or empress.
Vocabulary.example: The emperor built roads to make travel easier throughout the empire.

Vocabulary.mean: Goods are anything that can be bought or sold.
Vocabulary.example: Shoes, hats, dresses and purses were the goods she wanted to buy.

Vocabulary.mean: To heed something means to obey or follow it.
Vocabulary.example: You should heed the advice on the sign and not drive so fast.

Vocabulary.mean: To hitchhike means to travel by asking for rides from passing vehicles.
Vocabulary.example: She didn’t have a car, so she hitchhiked several miles to her brother’s home.

Vocabulary.mean: To mock someone means to tease them in a cruel way.
Vocabulary.example: The girls mocked Nancy because she was a new student.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone is neutral, then they do not help either of the two fighting sides.
Vocabulary.example: The girl’s friend remained neutral while the couple was arguing.

Vocabulary.mean: To persecute means to treat someone badly.
Vocabulary.example: Dan felt persecuted because he was smaller than the other boys at school.

Vocabulary.mean: Pity is the feeling of sadness and kindness for those who are suffering.
Vocabulary.example: Because she had pity for the lost boy, she helped him find his parents.

Vocabulary.mean: To reduce something means to make it less in size or number.
Vocabulary.example: When the store reduced its prices, people wanted to shop there.

Vocabulary.mean: A scribe was a person whose job was to copy written works.
Vocabulary.example: In Ancient Egypt, scribes recorded important events.

Vocabulary.mean: A temper is someone’s mood or a chance that they might get angry.
Vocabulary.example: She has a temper. Even the slightest mistakes make her angry.

Vocabulary.mean: A throne is the special chair in which a ruler sits.
Vocabulary.example: Nobody except the king and queen sat in the thrones in the great hall.

Vocabulary.mean: Unity is the state of people working together for a certain purpose.
Vocabulary.example: The project was finished early, thanks to the unity of the workers.

Vocabulary.mean: A victor is a group or person that wins in a contest.
Vocabulary.example: the end of the game, the blue team was the victor.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is accurate, it is completely correct.
Vocabulary.example: The story in the newspaper wasn’t very accurate.

Vocabulary.mean: To analyze something is to study it.
Vocabulary.example: The scientist will analyze the blood sample.

Vocabulary.mean: An asteroid is a giant rock from outer space.
Vocabulary.example: In 1908, a giant asteroid hit Siberia.

Vocabulary.mean: A controversy is a dispute about something that affects many people.
Vocabulary.example: There has been a lot of controversy over the judge’s decision.

Vocabulary.mean: To evolve is to change over time.
Vocabulary.example: Many people think that humans evolved from animals.

Vocabulary.mean: A factor is something that has an effect on the way another thing happens.
Vocabulary.example: Smoking is the main factor that causes lung cancer.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is genetic, it is related to the genes in one’s body.
Vocabulary.example: The color of one’s eyes is genetic.

Vocabulary.mean: A genome is the collection of all the genes in a living thing.
Vocabulary.example: Understanding the human genome may help cure many diseases.

Vocabulary.mean: To be identical is to be the same as someone or something else.
Vocabulary.example: James and John are identical twins.

Vocabulary.mean: An intellectual is a very smart person.
Vocabulary.example: We’ve always considered my Uncle Max the intellectual of the family.

Vocabulary.mean: A majority of something is almost all of the people orthings in that group.
Vocabulary.example: A majority of the people voted for Tom Smith in the election.

Vocabulary.mean: A mammal is an animal that usually has hair and is not born from an egg.
Vocabulary.example: Even though it lives in the water, whales are actually mammals.

Vocabulary.mean: To multiply is to increase in number.
Vocabulary.example: In the past year, the number of people at work multiplied by ten percent.

Vocabulary.mean: Offspring are the children of a person or the babies of an animal.
Vocabulary.example: The dog’s offspring had the same color of fur as she did.

Vocabulary.mean: A pesticide is a substance used to kill insects.
Vocabulary.example: The farmer sprayed his crops with a pesticide to keep bugs away.

Vocabulary.mean: To regulate something is to control how it happens.
Vocabulary.example: The bank regulates how much money people can borrow from it.

Vocabulary.mean: To reinforce something is to make it stronger.
Vocabulary.example: Peter reinforced his opinion with information from a book.

Vocabulary.mean: If one is stricken by a disease or problem, they are badly affected by it.
Vocabulary.example: Mike was stricken with a horrible illness.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is vast, it is very large.
Vocabulary.example: The wealthy man bought a vast amount of land in the countryside.

Vocabulary.mean: A vegetarian is someone who does not eat any meat products.
Vocabulary.example: I became a vegetarian because I don’t like the taste of meat.

Vocabulary.mean: To cherish something means to hold it as very important.
Vocabulary.example: I cherish this trophy I won.

Vocabulary.mean: Compassion is a feeling of understanding for someone who is hurt or suffering.
Vocabulary.example: The veterinarian had compassion for the sick little puppy.

Vocabulary.mean: Consent is permission to do something.
Vocabulary.example: Their mother gave the children consent to go outside and play.

Vocabulary.mean: The core is the center of something.
Vocabulary.example: The rings of a tree start forming at its core.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone is cunning, they are good at tricking people.
Vocabulary.example: The cunning child fooled his parents into thinking that he was kind.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone is dizzy, then they feel off balance as if they will fall down.
Vocabulary.example: The pregnant woman was dizzy after standing up too quickly.

Vocabulary.mean: Equilibrium is the balance between different forces.
Vocabulary.example: The sudden drop in prices upset the equilibrium of the economy.

Vocabulary.mean: To foster a feeling or a skill means to help it develop.
Vocabulary.example: She helped foster a sense of calm in the little boy.

Vocabulary.mean: To grind something means to break it into very small pieces or powder.
Vocabulary.example: She wanted to grind the beans, so she could brew some coffee.

Vocabulary.mean: To growl means to make a deep, angry sound.
Vocabulary.example: The dog started to growl at the man walking by.

Vocabulary.mean: Moderation is a state of being just enough but not too much.
Vocabulary.example: It is important to eat in moderation so that you can have a healthy body.

Vocabulary.mean: A predator is an animal that kills and eats other animals.
Vocabulary.example: The peregrine falcon is a predator that eats fish.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone is sane, they can think in a normal way.
Vocabulary.example: Oliver does not act like a sane person when he is angry.

Vocabulary.mean: A saucer is a small round dish that you set a cup on.
Vocabulary.example: He placed the spoon on the saucer.

Vocabulary.mean: To snatch something means to take it away with a quick motion.
Vocabulary.example: He was so hungry that he snatched an apple from a tree.

Vocabulary.mean: To stagger means to move in an unsteady way and almost fall over.
Vocabulary.example: He staggered around after having too much to drink.
